[b][color=white]Omnicoin Award now 10k OMC[/color][/b]
The award for the official cryptocurrency of Hack Forums has been raised from 5,000 Omnicoins to 10,000. In OMC to USD, that is roughly around $26-$28 at current rates. Long story short, the award price has been raised. The increase comes to play because it brings some more value to the coin, according to Omni. Additionally, the LTC award price has been raised to 4 LTC. Both hikes are too ensure that no awards will be lower than $20.[url=http://hackforums.net/member.php?action=profile&uid=1][color=#FF66FF][b]Omniscient[/b][/color][/url] states that "There is currently over 4 million OMC in circulation. That's a ton imho. Unsure how 30% of all OMC has been already mined but it has. It's going to be hard to stabilize the value when OMC is hardly rare at all. There are members who are probably holding hundreds of thousands of OMC."

[b][color=white]Post/Delete Method will not be Tolerated[/color][/b]
The post and delete rule, which prevents members from posting on a thread to shoot it to the top and then deleting their post, has recently been brought to attention after a number of members violated the rule. Around 10 members, possibly more, have been banned and Repfucked for posting and then deleting their posts within the marketplace. [b][color=white]Omni's Big Day[/color][/b]
The big day for the Boss finally has come. [url=http://hackforums.net/member.php?action=profile&uid=1][color=#FF66FF][b]Omniscient[/b][/color][/url], owner of Hack Forums recently celebrated his 44th birthday. Many members sent him gifts from his Amazon wishlist which, at the time, was displayed in his signature for at least a month prior. At this moment in time, HF is 7 years old! It's honestly amazing how [url=http://hackforums.net/member.php?action=profile&uid=1][color=#FF66FF][b]Omniscient[/b][/color][/url] puts in all the effort he currently does for the community considering how busy he is behind the scenes. Many members have been on this site since its conception, and stayed until now. As Omni stated on his thread, "HF continues to move forward and while I'm getting older many of you are simply growing up and becoming adults. HF is now over 7 years old. Members who joined in their teens are now in college, having their own children, and working toward careers. It's pretty cool imho. I get lots of great feedback on how HF has changed lives. It's also changed mine and I don't ever forget that. I'm very blessed to have this community. Through each days struggle I learn to be a better person. Thank you, thank you all." Once again, Happy Birthday Omni!

[b][color=white]Is the Proof-of-Work Conecept Outdated?[/color][/b]
As Omnicoin silently continues to function as it has always done, the community is beginning to worry about the proof-of-work concept. Most of the new altcoins incorporate proof-of-stake in some way, those who don't seem to be stillborn. Is this a sign that we should change too, before it's too late? Making the switch to proof-of-stake would radically change the direction of the coin. First and foremost, no more coins can be generated. This would prevent inflation and help reducing the currently abundant supply. On the other hand, the switch would render miners useless, potentially leaving the mining users in the red. [spoiler=][b][url=http://hackforums.net/member.php?action=profile&uid=1148878][color=#FFA500]Clique:[/url][/b][/color]  Welcome to the 205th edition of the HackForums weekly news! This week we're joined with an HF veteran, Wafflemonger. Any shoutouts to start this interview off?

[b][url=http://hackforums.net/member.php?action=profile&uid=1148878][color=#FFA500]Clique:[/url][/b][/color] Just curious, how long have you been affiliated with with the MRT?

[b][url=http://hackforums.net/member.php?action=profile&uid=1148878][color=#FFA500]Clique:[/url][/b][/color] Did you have an interest in malware removal and computer security before you signed up on the forum?
[color=white][b][url=http://hackforums.net/member.php?action=profile&uid=8383]Wafflemonger[/url]:[/b][/color] Yes I have actually. My whole interest actually started when I was 14 years old, so about 8 years ago. I had no idea that Hackforums even existed back then.

[b][url=http://hackforums.net/member.php?action=profile&uid=1148878][color=#FFA500]Clique:[/url][/b][/color] What's your backstory on how you discovered this board, anyways? How different was it back in 2008?
[color=white][b][url=http://hackforums.net/member.php?action=profile&uid=8383]Wafflemonger[/url]:[/b][/color]  I actually discovered this forum through looking up how to phish believe it or not. I lurked for over a year barely making any posts. Back in 2008, Crow essentially led the forum and it was pretty heavy on blackhat material. So I discovered the forum purely due to blackhat reasons.

[b][url=http://hackforums.net/member.php?action=profile&uid=1148878][color=#FFA500]Clique:[/url][/b][/color] What's your opinion on the news team? Do you actually read through the articles that we put up?

I generally only read through them when it has something that applies to me. However a long time ago I created a malware removal guide for The Alliance. I had submitted this guide to be mentioned in the news article, but I didn't see it in that specific edition so I stopped looking for it. Then about 2 months later, I searched my name on Hackforums for the hell of it and saw that my guide was actually listed in a future news edition. Also, I like reading about people that get banned. That's a pretty cool section XD.

[b][url=http://hackforums.net/member.php?action=profile&uid=1148878][color=#FFA500]Clique:[/url][/b][/color]  Could you say that Hackforums is going in the right direction?
[color=white][b][url=http://hackforums.net/member.php?action=profile&uid=8383]Wafflemonger[/url]:[/b][/color] Well a lot of the sections in HF don't really apply to me. I mean I've never purchased a single item from hackforums and I really don't plan to, so that cuts off at least half the forum. The part of Hackforums that I do frequent generally has a more mature attitude, like the Innuendo section, White Hat Help section, etc. So yes, I would say that based off of what I partake in, Hackforums is going in the right direction.

[b][url=http://hackforums.net/member.php?action=profile&uid=1148878][color=#FFA500]Clique:[/url][/b][/color] Could you see yourself still browsing this site years from now?
[color=white][b][url=http://hackforums.net/member.php?action=profile&uid=8383]Wafflemonger[/url]:[/b][/color]  It all depends on what happens after I graduate. I have no idea where my life will be headed so I cannot really comment on something so uncertain. However, I can say that I personally wouldn't have a problem with it as I am currently learning the ins and outs of malware removal from the MRT team, so I hope that I can apply that knowledge to better assist other users on the forum.

[b][url=http://hackforums.net/member.php?action=profile&uid=1148878][color=#FFA500]Clique:[/url][/b][/color]  Wise words. Any tips for someone whose looking to get into the whole world of malware removal/computer security?
[b][url=http://hackforums.net/member.php=action=profile&uid=8383]Wafflemonger[/url]:[/b] Well, the first place someone that is totally new to malware removal can start is guides. How I learned is through actually reading solutions to other people's problems on another site (Geekstogo). However before any of that, a person should learn how the computer itself works. There's really no way to begin removing malware if you have no idea what's supposed to be there in the first place. The next step would be to learn how malware itself works. You can't really defend from something or remove something when you have no idea how that something will be attacking the system.

[b][color=white]Hackers Exploit Human Emotion of Robin Williams' Passing[/color][/b]
The late comedian and actor Robin Williams' untimely death has been used as an attack vector for malicious black-hat hackers on Facebook and other social media. A link to a download of a malicious file is sent with the headline [i]"ROBIN WILLIAMS SAYS GOODBYE WITH HIS VIDEO PHONE"[/i]. The intent was to lure unsuspecting social media users to a malicious website. This social engineering tactic has been used before and has proven quite successful. The merciless, abhorrent hackers who use this as an attack vector, however, are continuing to do so. Once lured to the site, you are expected to either fill out a survey or download a "Facebook Media Plugin" in order to view the video. All though it would be incredible to hear the final words of the comedy legend, do not assume that any links are true.
     
[b][color=white]Anonymous Hackers Threaten Ferguson Police Department[/color][/b]
As many of you are aware, the tragic murder of an unarmed 17-year old boy named Michael Brown by a Ferguson police officer has drawn the attention of the nation at large. The infamous hacker collective "Anonymous" has decided to take action if need be. They are demanding that legislation be enforced pertaining to the humane treatment of citizens by law enforcement officers. Their promise is that if sufficient action is not performed soon, they will leak private and highly sensitive information on every member of the Ferguson Police Department as well as stealing databases, e-mails, and other private data. These groups of hackers' no-holds-barred mentality is rather severe, but they justify their actions by claiming it is for the greater good of society.
     
[b][color=white]All-Seeing Satellite[/color][/b]
A relatively-new program called the "Worldview 3" project was finally put into fruition when a satellite was launched into orbit on Tuesday August 12th, 2014. A USA-based company, DigiGlobe, developed the camera for this project and it is so powerful that it will be able to see your face from orbit. Surely only law enforcement and protective agencies will have access to this, right? Companies such as Google, NASA, Microsoft, FBI, NSA, and National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency will all have access to this satellite. This is a completely new and invasive spying tactic set in place by the government and national conglomerate businesses.[/align][/spoiler][/align]

[b][color=white]New Google Chrome Version Fixes 12 Vulnerabilities[/color][/b]
Google has released its new Google Chrome update which includes a fix for 12 different vulnerabilities. Those bugs where found by independent security researchers who reported them using the Bug Bounty program of Google and by doing so, received their rewards. For a use-after-free bug found on Chrome's web sockets part (CVE-2014-3165), a researcher has been awarded 1,500 Euros. Another researcher has received money for finding a serious bug involving the SPDY protocol. To fix the SPDY protocol bug, Google Chrome programmers decided to turn off SPDY and QUIC session pooling in their latest release.
     
[b][color=white]Anonymous Hacked The Ferguson Police Website[/color][/b]
After the shooting of a 18-year-old boy named Michael Brown, Anonymous, a hacktivist group, hacked into the Ferguson Police website in order to collect information about the incident. Anonymous posted on Twitter a large amount of found information and uploaded videos regarding the shooting on YouTube. Michael Brown, an unarmed man, has been shot multiple times by a police officer and had his dead body left on the street for many hours. Henceforth, Ferguson police has been accused of racist attacks and assaults.
     
[b][color=white]Vunlerability On BlackBerry's Wi-Fi File Sharing Feature[/color][/b]
A team of security researchers of the Mozhero company have found a serious vulnerability on BlackBerry's wi-fi file sharing feature. According to the report, a malicious user can get access to the file system of the phone by exploiting the aforementioned vulnerability. In order to gain access to the file system, an attacker must connect to the file sharing service of a vulnerable BlackBerry phone, which, according to the company, is disabled by default. This means that the attacker must convince the victim to enable it. According to BlackBerry, however, the BlackBerry OS version 10.2.1.1925 is not vulnerable to the bug.[/align][/spoiler][/align]

[align=center][spoiler=][align=left]
     
[b][color=white]AMD is Gearing Up to Enter the SSD Business[/color][/b]
AMD is in the business of a lot of things already: processors, graphics cards, and really almost all computer related components; it's hard to believe they haven't gotten into SSDs already. This is all about to change very soon seeing as AMD is looking to get into making SSDs. The company will be bringing the SSD line to the market under the branding of Radeon R7, which is a pretty renowned thing at this point. The SSDs will be geared towards gamers and be available in 120GB, 240GB, and 480GB versions. The read and write speeds seem to be up there with similar SSDs from companies such as Samsung. This is really all we know about specs until the SSDs launch later this year.
     
[b][color=white]Smartwatch Pioneers Meta Come Back With a High-End Alternative to Pebble[/color][/b]
Pebble wasn't really known for much until it made the smartwatch that became almost a household name overnight. Pebble wasn't always this well known, though. Back when Pebble was first starting and only had a BlackBerry accessory, the biggest brand of technology wearables was MetaWatch, which was a company based out of Fossil. [b][color=white]U.S. Schools Struggling to Assimilate Large Numbers of Immigrant Students[/color][/b]
In schools accepting immigrant students around the country, there has been a growing number of Hispanic children being enrolled in schools. This so far has caused a great amount of stress on the faculty that run these schools. According to one teacher, about 2 new students per day were arriving in her English for Speakers of Other Languages Class for over a month. Hundreds of trailers are being used to extend schools for the influx of these students, and the number only keeps increasing. As part of a construction project with a budget of a billion dollars, a new resort community with hotels (and even a gondola system which will allow tourists to access the floor of the canyon) is being built. There has been some controversy over if construction should even take place in such a sacred place held only by nature. Only time will tell the fate of such an untouched part of the canyon
